subsc: Central government administration,Roads and highways,Railways,Ports, waterways and shipping

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Forest Products
            Transport Project in Uruguay were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was moderately satisfactory. Lessons learned
            included: 1) The impact of funding constraints and fiscal
            policies should not be underestimated. The lack of fiscal
            space and/or counterpart funding remains a major risk for
            fiscally constrained countries; 2) Multiple operations
            contribute to additional flexibility and long-term
            sustainability of investment; 3) A multimodal transport
            project can maximize the development impact but requires
            flexibility during supervision; 4) Maintaining a strong
            policy dialogue during supervision can significantly support
            reforms. This project gave another example of the difficulty
            of reforming railways, even if all the possible support was
            assured during preparation; and 5) The design of
            institutional arrangements and forms of private
            participation should be adapted to the country's
            specificities. The concession of operation of forest
            products in the State Railway Administration (AFE) did not
            occur despite the need to improve its efficiency and strong
            initial support.
